message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Erythroblastosis fetalis can occur when an Rh-negative mother is sensitized to the Rh factor from an Rh-positive fetus. It is not specific to blood type, so options B and C are incorrect. Rho(D) immune globulin should be administered during the second and third trimesters, not the first. IgG, not IgM, crosses the placenta in EF and causes erythrocyte hemolysis in the fetus. Therefore, the correct answer is (A).

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The blood type of the mother is B- and the father is B+. This means that there is a possibility of Rh incompatibility between the mother and the fetus. Erythroblastosis fetalis can occur with an Rh-negative mother and an Rh-positive father or with other blood types that are incompatible. Rho(D) immune globulin is typically administered during the third trimester or after delivery, not the first trimester, to prevent the formation of maternal antibodies. The combination of an Rh-negative mother and an Rh-positive fetus can cause the condition, but it's not the only cause. In EF, IgG, not IgM, crosses the placenta and causes erythrocyte hemolysis in the fetus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Erythroblastosis fetalis is caused by Rh incompatibility between mother and fetus. An Rh-negative mother carrying an Rh-positive fetus is at risk for developing antibodies against Rh antigen present on fetal erythrocytes. Therefore, option A is correct. Rho(D) immune globulin should be given in the third trimester and within 72 hours after delivery to prevent sensitization in the Rh-negative mother carrying an Rh-positive fetus. Option B is incorrect. Option C is incorrect as it is the opposite scenario. Option D is incorrect as it is IgG, not IgM that crosses the placenta and causes erythrocyte hemolysis in the fetus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Erythroblastosis fetalis can occur with an Rh-negative mother and an Rh-positive father, as in this case. Rho(D) immune globulin should be administered during the third trimester and after delivery, not during the first trimester. The combination of an Rh-negative mother and an Rh-positive fetus will cause the mother to produce antibodies against the fetal Rh factor, but it is not the cause of erythroblastosis fetalis. In EF, IgG crosses the placenta and causes erythrocyte hemolysis in the fetus, not IgM.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The blood type mismatch between the mother (B-) and father (B+) can lead to antibody formation in the mother which can cross the placenta and cause hemolysis of the fetal red blood cells, leading to EF. Option A is the correct statement as it is possible for an Rh-negative mother and Rh-positive father to produce an Rh-positive fetus who can develop EF. Option B is incorrect as Rho(D) immune globulin is administered during the third trimester or after delivery, not the first trimester. Option C is incorrect as an Rh-negative mother and Rh-positive fetus can lead to hemolytic disease of the newborn but not EF. Option D is incorrect as IgG, not IgM, crosses the placenta and causes erythrocyte hemolysis in the fetus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Erythroblastosis fetalis is a condition in which maternal antibodies cross the placenta and attack fetal red blood cells. The most common cause is Rh factor incompatibility, which can occur when an Rh-negative mother carries an Rh-positive fetus (answer A). Rho(D) immune globulin should be administered during the third trimester and after delivery, not the first trimester (answer B). An Rh-negative mother and an Rh-positive fetus will not cause the condition but rather increase the risk of it (answer C). In EF, IgG crosses the placenta and causes erythrocyte hemolysis in the fetus, not IgM (answer D).

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Choice (A) is correct because erythroblastosis fetalis can occur when the mother is Rh-negative and the father is Rh-positive and the fetus is Rh-positive. Choice (B) is incorrect because Rho(D) immune globulin is typically administered during the 28th week of pregnancy and again within 72 hours after delivery to prevent sensitization in the next pregnancy. Choice (C) is incorrect because the condition occurs when the mother is Rh-negative and the fetus is Rh-positive. Choice (D) is incorrect because it is IgG, not IgM, that crosses the placenta and causes erythrocyte hemolysis in the fetus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Erythroblastosis fetalis is caused by incompatibility between a mother's and fetus's blood. It can occur with an Rh-negative mother and Rh-positive father, which is the case here. Rho(D) immune globulin is typically administered during the third trimester and postpartum to prevent sensitization of an Rh-negative mother to Rh-positive fetal blood. The combination of an Rh-positive mother and an Rh-negative fetus can lead to Rh disease, not erythroblastosis fetalis. In EF, IgG, not IgM, crosses the placenta and causes erythrocyte hemolysis in the fetus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Erythroblastosis fetalis occurs when there is an incompatibility between the blood types of the mother and fetus, leading to hemolysis of fetal red blood cells. It can occur with an Rh-negative mother and Rh-positive father, among other blood type incompatibilities. Rho(D) immune globulin is typically administered during the third trimester or after delivery, not the first trimester. An Rh-positive mother and Rh-negative fetus would not cause erythroblastosis fetalis, as the fetus would not develop an immune reaction against the mother's blood. IgG, not IgM, crosses the placenta and causes erythrocyte hemolysis in EF.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Erythroblastosis fetalis is a condition where the mother's immune system attacks the red blood cells of the fetus. This can occur if the mother is Rh-negative and the father is Rh-positive, meaning the fetus could inherit the Rh antigen from the father. Option (A) is the correct answer. Option (B) is incorrect because Rho(D) immune globulin should be administered during the third trimester, not the first. Option (C) is incorrect because the combination of an Rh-negative mother and an Rh-positive fetus is actually what puts the fetus at risk for erythroblastosis fetalis. Option (D) is incorrect because IgG, not IgM, crosses the placenta and causes hemolysis in the fetus.
